metadata.titleEn: Fraction of Absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) across Tibetan Plateau from 1987 to 2020
metadata.description: Fraction of Absorbed Photosynthetically Active Radiation (FPAR) is a key physiological variable in the study of carbon cycling and is one of the basic variables to describe vegetation ecosystems. The classification results of surface vegetation types in Qinghai-Tibet Plateau region are obtained based on the Landsat reflectance data(30m spatial resolution). According to NDVI of different vegetation types, the remote sensing inversion model is constructed to produce the growing season FPAR products for each vegetation type. This product can be used as one of the parameters to calculate vegetation carbon sequestration and evaluate vegetation ecosystem status.
metadata.instructions: File naming: The FPAR dataset is stored in Geotiff format in blocks,and the file name is "N??E??.tif", where N?? represents the latitude of the upper left corner of the corresponding image block, and E?? represents Corresponds to the longitude of the upper left corner of the image block. Data reading method: you can directly use any software that supports tif image to open; it is recommended to use QGIS, ArcGIS, ENVI and other geographic information related software to open.

background: Global land-cover information, as used by the scientific community, governments, and international organizations, is critical to the understanding of environmental changes, food security, conservation, and the coordination of actions needed to mitigate and adapt to global change. These data also play an important role in improving the performance of models of the ecosystem, hydrology, and atmosphere. Due to the frequent and large area coverage that it provides, more and more attention has been attached to using remote sensing technology for global land-cover mapping. In past decades, several global land-cover products have been produced at various spatial resolutions ranging from 1 km to 300 m. However, owing to differences in classification accuracy, thematic detail, classification schemes, and spatial resolution, the harmonization of these land-cover products is usually difficult, and their quality is also far from satisfactory for many fine applications. Recently, thanks to free access to fine-resolution remote sensing imagery (Landsat and Sentinel-2), combined with rapidly increasing data storage and computation capabilities, global land-cover products at fine spatial resolutions (10 and 30 m) have been successfully developed. Although these products permit the detection of land information at the scale of most human activity and offer increased flexibility for the environmental model parameterization needed for global land-cover studies, the simple classification system and large amount of manual work required (manual collection of training samples and knowledge-based interactive verification) limit their greater use in many specific and fine applications at regional or global scales.
research objective: In this study, a novel global 30 m land-cover classification with a fine classification system for the year 2015 (GLC_FCS30-2015) was produced by combining time series of Landsat imagery and high-quality training data from the GSPECLib (Global Spatial Temporal Spectra Library) on the Google Earth Engine computing platform.
challenges: As Giri et al. (2013) and Ban et al. (2015) stated, there are a number of challenges to overcome in producing a fine-resolution characterization of global land cover. These include the unavailability of timely, accurate, and sufficient training data; the high cost of collecting satellite data with consistent global coverage; difficulties in preparing image mosaics; and the need for high-performance computing facilities. Firstly, Foody and Arora (2010) stated that the training data had more impact on the classification results than the selection of the classifier: the collection of timely, accurate, and sufficient training data is especially important for global or regional land-cover mapping.
methods: First, the global training data from the GSPECLib were developed by applying a series of rigorous filters to the CCI_LC (Climate Change Initiative Global Land Cover) land-cover and MCD43A4 NBAR products (MODIS Nadir Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Function-Adjusted Reflectance). Secondly, a local adaptive random forest model was built for each 5°×5° geographical tile by using the multi-temporal Landsat spectral and texture features and the corresponding training data, and the GLC_FCS30-2015 land-cover product containing 30 land-cover types was generated for each tile. Lastly, the GLC_FCS30-2015 was validated using three different validation systems (containing different land-cover details) using 44,043 validation samples.
dataset: Taking account of the frequent contamination of cloud in the remote sensing imagery, particularly in the tropics, all Landsat-8 surface reflectance (SR) imagery from 2014–2016 archived on the GEE platform was collected for the nominal year 2015. In this study, the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) DEM, which has a spatial resolution of 30 m and covers the area between 60◦N and 56◦S, and the slope and aspect variables, were used as the classification features. In this study, the global land-cover classification neglected the impervious surface land-cover type when building the classification model; instead, existing global 30 m impervious surface products for 2015 (MSMT_IS30-2015) were directly superimposed over the global land-cover classifications (Zhang et al., 2020). Overall, after the combination of the auxiliary datasets from multiple sources and careful rechecking by several interpreters, a total of 44 043 validation samples for 24 fine land-cover types were finally collected.
findings: The validation results indicated that the GLC_FCS30-2015 achieved an overall accuracy of 82.5% and a kappa coefficient of 0.784 for the level-0 validation system (9 basic land-cover types), an overall accuracy of 71.4% and kappa coefficient of 0.686 for the UN-LCCS (United Nations Land Cover Classification System) level-1 system (16 LCCS land-cover types), and an overall accuracy of 68.7% and kappa coefficient of 0.662 for the UN-LCCS level-2 system (24 fine land-cover types). The comparisons against other land-cover products (CCI_LC, MCD12Q1, FROM_GLC, and GlobeLand30) indicated that GLC_FCS30-2015 provides more spatial details than CCI_LC-2015 and MCD12Q1-2015 and a greater diversity of land-cover types than FROM_GLC-2015 and GlobeLand30-2010. They also showed that GLC_FCS30-2015 achieved the best overall accuracy of 82.5% against FROM_GLC-2015 of 59.1% and GlobeLand30-2010 of 75.9%. Therefore, it is concluded that the GLC_FCS30-2015 product is the first global land-cover dataset that provides a fine classification system (containing 16 global LCCS land-cover types as well as 14 detailed and regional land-cover types) with high classification accuracy at 30 m.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'FPAR' in the context of carbon cycle research?
Definition.Answer: FPAR, or Fraction of Photosynthetically Active Radiation, is a key physiological variable in carbon cycle research. It represents the fraction of incoming solar radiation in the photosynthetically active spectrum that is absorbed by vegetation. This variable is fundamental for describing the state of vegetation ecosystems and is used to calculate vegetation carbon sequestration, assess ecosystem health, and support ecological and forestry applications.

Definition.Question: What do 'remote sensing technology' and 'global land-cover mapping' entail?
Definition.Answer: Remote sensing technology refers to the use of satellite or aerial imagery to observe and measure various characteristics of the Earth's surface without physical contact. Global land-cover mapping involves using this technology to classify different types of land cover across the globe, which is crucial for understanding environmental changes, food security, conservation, and global change adaptation efforts. This process often involves collecting and analyzing imagery data to produce land-cover products at various spatial resolutions.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using Landsat imagery for FPAR products in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau compare to the global land-cover classification approach using Landsat imagery and GSPECLib training data?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection for FPAR products in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau focuses on LANDSAT reflectance data with a spatial resolution of 30 meters for vegetation type classification, emphasizing local NDVI differences to model vegetation growth. In contrast, the global land-cover classification approach combines multi-temporal Landsat imagery with high-quality training data from the GSPECLib on the Google Earth Engine platform, employing a local adaptive random forest model for each geographical tile.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences between the challenges faced in collecting data for FPAR products and global land-cover classifications?
Comparison.Answer: Both domains face challenges related to the availability and quality of training data and the need for high-performance computing facilities. However, while FPAR data collection emphasizes detailed local vegetation characteristics, global land-cover classifications deal with broader challenges such as consistent global coverage and the preparation of image mosaics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying factors contribute to the challenges in producing fine-resolution land-cover datasets in the context of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The challenges in producing fine-resolution land-cover datasets include the unavailability of timely, accurate, and sufficient training data, the high cost of collecting satellite data with consistent global coverage, difficulties in preparing image mosaics, and the need for high-performance computing facilities.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is remote sensing technology increasingly important for global land-cover mapping and understanding changes in vegetation ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Remote sensing technology is crucial for global land-cover mapping due to its ability to provide frequent and large area coverage, which is essential for understanding environmental changes and improving the performance of ecosystem, hydrology, and atmospheric models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for high classification accuracy and detailed classification systems in land-cover datasets used for ecological and carbon cycle studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: High classification accuracy and detailed classification systems are necessary in land-cover datasets because they permit the detection of land information at the scale of most human activity, offer increased flexibility for environmental model parameterization, and improve the quality of applications like evaluating vegetation ecosystem states and calculating carbon fixation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using high-resolution Landsat imagery combined with GSPECLib training data for global land-cover classification?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The combination of high-resolution Landsat imagery with GSPECLib training data can result in the development of a global 30 m land-cover classification with a fine classification system, achieving high classification accuracy and allowing for detailed environmental model parameterization at the scale of most human activities.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from the challenges in collecting timely, accurate, and sufficient training data for global land-cover mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The challenges in collecting timely, accurate, and sufficient training data can significantly impact the classification results, potentially limiting the accuracy and applicability of the global or regional land-cover mapping, and thus affecting the reliability of the resulting datasets for fine applications.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended outcomes of developing a novel global land-cover classification system using fine-resolution remote sensing imagery?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended outcomes include improving the understanding of environmental changes, enhancing food security, supporting conservation efforts, and enabling the coordination of actions needed to mitigate and adapt to global change. The fine-resolution land-cover classification aims to address challenges related to classification accuracy, thematic detail, and spatial resolution, providing a more detailed and accurate dataset for ecosystem, hydrology, and atmospheric models.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to construct remote sensing inversion models to produce FPAR products for different vegetation types?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Constructing remote sensing inversion models to produce FPAR products is important for calculating vegetation carbon sequestration and evaluating vegetation ecosystem status. These products are vital for ecological and environmental research, offering insights into the health and dynamics of vegetation systems, which are crucial for forest management and other ecological applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in constructing a remote sensing inversion model for generating FPAR products from Landsat reflectance data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To construct a remote sensing inversion model for generating FPAR products, the process involves using LANDSAT reflectance data at a 30-meter spatial resolution to derive surface vegetation type classifications. Based on differences in NDVI values among various vegetation types, a remote sensing inversion model is built to produce FPAR products for each vegetation type during the growing season.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the collection of training data from global sources, like GSPECLib, integrated into the development of a global land-cover classification system?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The collection of training data from global sources like GSPECLib involves applying rigorous filters to existing land-cover products such as the CCI_LC and MODIS NBAR products. This data is then used in combination with multi-temporal Landsat spectral and texture features to build a local adaptive random forest model for each geographical tile, thereby integrating it into the development of a global land-cover classification system.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are employed to address the challenges of cloud contamination in remote sensing imagery for land-cover classification?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address cloud contamination in remote sensing imagery, particularly in tropical regions, the methodological approach involves collecting all available Landsat-8 surface reflectance imagery over the nominal year of study. This approach helps mitigate the effects of cloud contamination by increasing the temporal coverage and selecting cloud-free observations for land-cover classification.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the effective collection and processing of remote sensing data for land-cover classification at a fine spatial resolution?
Enablement.Answer: The advancements in free access to fine-resolution remote sensing imagery from sources like Landsat and Sentinel-2, coupled with increasing data storage and computation capabilities, enable the effective collection and processing of data for land-cover classification at a fine spatial resolution.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of multi-temporal spectral and texture features from satellite imagery enable detailed classification of land-cover types?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of multi-temporal spectral and texture features from Landsat imagery allows for building a local adaptive random forest model for detailed land-cover classification, enabling the production of fine classification systems like the GLC_FCS30-2015.

Enablement.Question: What challenges need to be addressed to enable the widespread use of global land-cover products with fine classification systems?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the unavailability of timely, accurate, and sufficient training data, high costs of consistent global satellite data coverage, difficulties in preparing image mosaics, and the need for high-performance computing facilities to enable broader use of global land-cover products with fine classification systems.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in collecting training data for regional land-cover mapping?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in collecting training data for regional land-cover mapping include the unavailability of timely, accurate, and sufficient training data, which is crucial for classification results. Additionally, the high cost of collecting satellite data with consistent global coverage and the difficulties in preparing image mosaics contribute to these challenges.

Expectation.Question: What expectations exist around the use of remote sensing technology in improving global land-cover mapping, and why might these not be fully realized?
Expectation.Answer: Remote sensing technology is expected to improve global land-cover mapping by providing frequent and large area coverage. However, expectations might not be fully realized due to the challenges in harmonizing land-cover products, differences in classification accuracy, thematic detail, classification schemes, and spatial resolution, which make quality improvement difficult for many fine applications.

Expectation.Question: Why might global land-cover datasets struggle to provide sufficient detail for specific regional applications despite advances in computing and data availability?
Expectation.Answer: Global land-cover datasets might struggle to provide sufficient detail for specific regional applications because, despite advances in computing and data availability, the simple classification system and the large amount of manual work required, such as manual collection of training samples and knowledge-based interactive verification, limit their greater use in specific and fine applications.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of using LANDSAT and Sentinel-2 data for producing high-resolution global land-cover classifications?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of LANDSAT and Sentinel-2 data is considered effective for producing high-resolution global land-cover classifications due to their fine spatial resolutions (10 and 30 m) and the ability to detect land information at scales relevant to human activity. However, challenges such as the need for accurate training data and high-performance computing facilities must be addressed to improve their effectiveness further.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the challenges of harmonizing different global land-cover products considering differences in classification accuracy and thematic detail?
Judgmental.Answer: Harmonizing different global land-cover products is challenging due to variations in classification accuracy, thematic detail, classification schemes, and spatial resolution. These discrepancies make it difficult to achieve satisfactory quality for fine applications, and require innovative approaches, such as integrating multiple datasets and validation systems, to improve the harmonization process.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential improvement areas for data collection methods in producing global land-cover datasets with higher classification accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential improvement areas for data collection methods include enhancing the availability and quality of training data, reducing the cost of satellite data collection, and increasing computational capabilities. Developing adaptive models and leveraging auxiliary datasets can also contribute to higher classification accuracy in global land-cover datasets.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing technology contributes to creating accurate global land-cover classifications at fine resolutions.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing technology provides frequent and large area coverage that is crucial for global land-cover mapping. By utilizing fine-resolution imagery from sources like Landsat and Sentinel-2, along with improved data storage and computational capabilities, it is possible to develop detailed and accurate land-cover classifications at resolutions of 10 to 30 meters.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in collecting sufficient training data for global land-cover mapping.
Assertion.Answer: Some challenges in collecting sufficient training data for global land-cover mapping include the unavailability of timely, accurate, and sufficient data, the high cost of obtaining consistent global satellite coverage, and the difficulties in preparing image mosaics. Training data has more impact on classification results than the choice of classifier, making its collection especially important.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how validation samples are used to assess the accuracy of land-cover classification products.
Assertion.Answer: Validation samples are critical for assessing the accuracy of land-cover classification products. In the study, a total of 44,043 validation samples were collected for 24 fine land-cover types to evaluate the classification accuracy. The validation process involved multiple systems with varying levels of land-cover detail, ensuring the product's accuracy and reliability compared to existing land-cover datasets.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges associated with collecting accurate and sufficient training data for global land-cover mapping using remote sensing technology.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the unavailability of timely, accurate, and sufficient training data; high costs of collecting satellite data with consistent global coverage; difficulties in preparing image mosaics; and the need for high-performance computing facilities. The training data significantly impacts classification results, making its collection especially important for global or regional land-cover mapping.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential data collection methods that could improve the accuracy of FPAR products for vegetation analysis on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential methods include utilizing fine-resolution remote sensing imagery like Landsat and Sentinel-2 to detect vegetation information at a human activity scale, leveraging multi-temporal spectral and texture features from these images, and employing high-quality training data from global spatial libraries to refine remote sensing inversion models for FPAR products, enhancing accuracy and ecological assessments.
